title: The Class Keeper
subtitle: Understanding C# Objects
description:
# The Scroll of Classes

You've been using dictionaries to store character data, but C# has something even more powerful: **classes**! Classes let you create custom types with properties and methods.

## What is a Class?

A class is a blueprint for creating objects. Think of it like a character sheet template that defines what properties a character has.

```csharp
public class Hero
{
    public string Name { get; set; }
    public int Health { get; set; }
    public int Level { get; set; }
}
```

## Creating Objects from Classes

Once you have a class, you can create instances (objects) from it:

```csharp
Hero hero1 = new Hero
{
    Name = "Aria",
    Health = 100,
    Level = 5
};

Console.WriteLine(hero1.Name);    // Prints: Aria
Console.WriteLine(hero1.Health);  // Prints: 100
```

## Properties vs Fields

C# uses **properties** (with `{ get; set; }`) instead of simple fields:

```csharp
public class Item
{
    public string Name { get; set; }     // Property
    public int Value { get; set; }       // Property
}
```

## Your Quest

1. A `Weapon` class has been created with properties for Name, Damage, and Type
2. Create a new Weapon object called `excalibur` with:
   - Name: `"Excalibur"`
   - Damage: `50`
   - Type: `"Sword"`
3. Print all three properties
4. Change the damage to `75`
5. Print the updated damage
hints: Create objects with: ClassName objectName = new ClassName { Property = value };
Access properties with dot notation: objectName.PropertyName
Update properties the same way: objectName.PropertyName = newValue;
Use PascalCase for class and property names in C#
Don't forget semicolons after each statement!
